name: (2E)-2-(1H-Benzimidazol-2-yl)-3-(3-hydroxyphenyl)acrylonitrile
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1567

name: (2E)-2-(1H-Benzimidazol-2-yl)-3-(3-hydroxyphenyl)acrylonitrile
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1567
Reason:
The compound in question contains several functional groups that will influence its melting point. The basic structure we can consider as a starting point is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. From there, we need to account for the following functional groups and structural features: 
- Benzimidazole moiety: +150 (this is a rigid and planar heteroaromatic system which provides significant stabilization and raises the melting point substantially). 
- Phenyl group: +30 (this brings additional pi-pi interactions and further rigidity to the structure). 
- Acrylonitrile moiety: +100 (the carbon-carbon triple bond and the nitrile group contribute to the rigidity and polar character of the molecule). 
- Hydroxyl group: +10 (hydrogen bonding can increase the melting point, but since there's only one such group its effect is moderate). 
Adding all these together gives an estimated change of +290 degrees Celsius to the base structure of benzene.
